DataElement.preferredName: Patient Iobenguane Malignant Neoplasm Negation Avidity Increased Uptake Present Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator that asks whether increased uptake was present in MIBG non avid disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Iobenguane Malignant Neoplasm Negation Avidity Increased Uptake Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a patient's history of Iobenguane (MIBG) and increased uptake (more absorption by a tissue of some substance) in non-avid disease (reduced or absent uptake of Iobenguane in tissues or tumor cells) present (existing in a specified place or at the specified time).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Iobenguane Malignant Neoplasm Negation Avidity Increase Uptake Present
Property.preferredDefinition: A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), localizes to adrenergic tissue and is taken up and accumulates in the granules of pre-synaptic adrenergic neurons. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.:Strength of binding, usually of a small molecule with multiple binding sites by a larger, particularly the binding of a complex antigen by an antibody.:Increase; a process of becoming larger or more numerous or more important.:The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Strength of binding, usually of a small molecule with multiple binding sites by a larger, particularly the binding of a complex antigen by an antibody.
A process of becoming larger, more numerous, more important, or more likely.
The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.
